--- Kenneth Stanley <kstanley@...> wrote:
> In fact, it sounds remarkably
> similar to the 
> people the author is criticizing- those who are
> supposedly set in 
> their close-minded ways.  After all, the author is
> essentially 
> advocating a multi-pronged, modular approach, in
> which lots 
> of "tools" are used together to produce the final
> product.  

Yeah, I thought the same thing.  Of course, it is
easier to criticize a given approach then to put forth
a comprehensive one of your own.  And much of the
criticism of approaches to AI research is justified.

But I don't think he was really being fair to the GA
approach.  

> But the funny thing is, you may notice, I never
> mentioned NN's or 
> GA's, but if you like my plan, you can't help but
> think, hmm NN's 
> and GA's sound like what I'm talking about.  Now the
> question is, 
> whose plan is actually new?

We're on the same page, of course.  There are very few
critics who won't admit the Byzantine complexity of
even rudimentary nervous systems.  Trying to
forward-engineer that level of complexity seems highly
unlikely, but you're right...this is the traditional
approach to AI.

I think we mostly agree that if very good AI is going
to be created, it will most likely be from the bottom
up, exploiting some key features of natural biological
processes and systems.

Derek
